title: Type hinting
snippet: Type hintingBasicamente simplifcar a leitura de codigo mostrando o tipo de cada variavel ou retorno.O type hinting não deixa ela estaticamente tipada, você pode ate colocar que quer receber uma string mas se receber um int… problema é seu.A partir do Python 3.5!A PEP que deu origem a ela é 484Mais usadospalavra_ou_letra: strnumero_inteiro: intnumero_flutuante: floatvalor_booleano: boolColeçõeslista: list[str]tupla: tuple[float]dicionario: dict[str, float]conjunto: set[int]Com funçõesVocê usa o -&gt; tipo: para definir o tipo de retornodef alguma_funcao_qualquer(palavra: str) -&gt; str: return palavra# Exemplo se tiver que colocar um valor padrãodef alguma_funcao_qualquer(numero: int = 0) -&gt; int: return numero# Exemplo de uma função que não retorn nadadef funcao_que_nao_retorna_nada(palavra: str) -&gt; None: print(palavra)

title: Ruby setup
snippet: Ruby setupEu sempre esqueço isso aqui, então fica ai o exemplo1. Instala o RBENVSe você tiver usando Fedora, se for outra distrosudo dnf install rbenv2. Inicia o RBENVrbenv initDepois de rodar ele, fecha e abre o terminal3. Instala a versão que quiserrbenv install 3.0.04. Setando a versão# setando a versão pra maquina inteirarbenv global 3.0.0# setando a versão apenas para esse diretoriorbenv local 3.0.0

title: Many to many SQLAlchemy
snippet: Many to manyEu sempre esqueço isso aqui, então fica ai o exemploPONTO DE ATENÇÃOSe for criar as tabelas e a relação delas do ZERO, crie primeiro as tabelas principais e depois você cria a tabela de relação e insere a relação na primeira tabela. No caso de tabelas já existentes basta seguir isso ai.1. Primeiro cria uma tabela como variavel# Tabela intermediária para a relação many-to-manystudents_courses = sa.Table( "students_courses", Base.metadata, sa.Column( "student_id", sa.Integer, sa.ForeignKey("students.id"), primary_key=True ), sa.Column( "course_id", sa.Integer, sa.ForeignKey("courses.id"), primary_key=True ),)2. Coloca as tabelas que vão ser ligadas depois desse codigoclass Student(Base): __tablename__ = "students" id = sa.Column(sa.Integer, primary_key=True) name = sa.Column(sa.String, nullable=False)class Course(Base): __tablename__ = "courses" id = sa.Column(sa.Integer, primary_key=True) title = sa.Column(sa.String, nullable=False)3. A ligação é isso aqui: # Relação many-to-many courses = sa.orm.relationship( "Course", secondary=students_courses, backref="students" )Você vai colocar isso na primeira tabela que você vai ligar. APENAS na PRIMEIRA. Motivo:backref="students"Isso vai criar automaticamente um campo na outra tabela que contem todo o conteudo do mesmo campo da outra tabela.PRONTO É ISSO AI!

title: How to set wallpaper on i3 WM
snippet: 1 - Let’s install nitrogenUse apt for debian based distrossudo dnf install nitrogen2 - Open nitrogen and set wallpaperThis is really straightforward so no tutorial for this3 - Let’s make a backup of our original i3 WM configcp ~/.config/i3/config ~/.config/i3/config.ori4 - Edit i3 WM configI gonna use NVIM to edit the config, you can use whatever editor you wantnvim ~/.config/i3/config5 - Inside of config fileWe gonna add this code to set wallpaper everytime i3 WM startsexec --no-startup-id nitrogen --restore6 - Save the changes and restart i3 WMSuper + Shift + r

title: How to change default terminal of i3 WM
snippet: 1 - First let’s make a backup of our original i3 WM configcp ~/.config/i3/config ~/.config/i3/config.ori2 - Edit i3 WM configI gonna use NVIM to edit the config, you can use whatever editor you wantnvim ~/.config/i3/config3 - Inside of config fileNow we’re gonna change this line (I’m alacritty user so I’m gonna change it to alacritty)bindsym $mod+Return exec alacritty4 - Save the changes and restart i3 WMSuper + Shift + r

title: How to fix battery percentage on i3 status
snippet: 1 - First let’s make a backup of our original i3 status configcp /etc/i3status.conf ~/.config/i3/i3status.conf2 - Edit i3status.confI gonna use NVIM to edit the config, you can use whatever editor you wantsudo nvim /etc/i3status.conf3 - Inside of config fileWe gonna add this codebattery all { ... last_full_capacity = true}4 - Save the changes and restart i3Super + Shift + r

title: How to change battery percentage to integer on i3 status
snippet: 1 - First let’s make a backup of our original i3 status configcp /etc/i3status.conf ~/.config/i3/i3status.conf2 - Edit i3status.confI gonna use NVIM to edit the config, you can use whatever editor you wantsudo nvim /etc/i3status.conf3 - Inside of config fileWe gonna add this codebattery all { ... integer_battery_capacity = true}4 - Save the changes and restart i3Super + Shift + r

title: How to add cpu temperature on i3 status
snippet: 1 - First let’s make a backup of our original i3 status configcp /etc/i3status.conf ~/.config/i3/i3status.conf2 - Edit i3status.confI gonna use NVIM to edit the config, you can use whatever editor you wantsudo nvim /etc/i3status.conf3 - Inside of config fileWe gonna add this codeorder += "cpu_temperature 0"cpu_temperature 0 { format = "%degrees °C 🌡️" path = "/sys/devices/platform/coretemp.0/hwmon/hwmon4/temp1_input"}4 - Save the changes and restart i3Super + Shift + r

title: How to add cpu usage on i3 status
snippet: 1 - First let’s make a backup of our original i3 status configcp /etc/i3status.conf ~/.config/i3/i3status.conf2 - Edit i3status.confI gonna use NVIM to edit the config, you can use whatever editor you wantsudo nvim /etc/i3status.conf3 - Inside of config fileWe gonna add this codeorder += "cpu_usage"cpu_usage { format = "%usage 📈"}4 - Save the changes and restart i3Super + Shift + r

title: How to change i3 status separator
snippet: 1 - First let’s make a backup of our original i3 WM configcp ~/.config/i3/config ~/.config/i3/config.ori2 - Edit i3 WM configI gonna use NVIM to edit the config, you can use whatever editor you wantnvim ~/.config/i3/config3 - Inside of config fileNow we’re gonna to add this line to make separator a blank spacebar { .... separator_symbol " "}4 - Save the changes and restart i3 WMSuper + Shift + r

title: How to add a clock with a different timezone on i3 status
snippet: 1 - First let’s make a backup of our original i3 status configcp /etc/i3status.conf ~/.config/i3/i3status.conf2 - Edit i3status.confI gonna use NVIM to edit the config, you can use whatever editor you wantsudo nvim /etc/i3status.conf3 - Inside of config fileWe gonna add a code like this, for this tutorial I’m gonna use Lisbon timezoneorder += "tztime lisbon"tztime lisbon { format = "%H:%M 🇵🇹" timezone = "Europe/Lisbon" hide_if_equals_localtime = true}4 - Save the changes and restart i3Super + Shift + r

title: How to move i3 status bar
snippet: 1 - First let’s make a backup of our original i3 WM configcp ~/.config/i3/config ~/.config/i3/config.ori2 - Edit i3 WM configI gonna use NVIM to edit the config, you can use whatever editor you wantnvim ~/.config/i3/config3 - Inside of config fileNow we’re gonna to add this line to move i3 status bar to topbar { .... position top}4 - Save the changes and restart i3 WMSuper + Shift + r

title: How to enable touchpad tap to click in i3 WM
snippet: DisclaimerWell, it actually isn’t related to i3 WM, i3 WM is just a window manager, it means it just adjust windows on your screen and that’s it. But if you’re on i3 WM and use a laptop like I do, it’s gonna be really helpful1 - Create /etc/X11/xorg.conf.d/touchpad-tap.confsudo nvim /etc/X11/xorg.conf.d/touchpad-tap.conf2 - Paste it inside of conf fileSection "InputClass" Identifier "libinput touchpad catchall" MatchIsTouchpad "on" MatchDevicePath "/dev/input/event*" Driver "libinput" Option "Tapping" "on"EndSection3 - Save it and restart your xorg session (just logout and login)

title: How to add apps on dmenu
snippet: DisclaimerWell, it actually isn’t related to i3 WM, i3 WM is just a window manager, it means it just adjust windows on your screen and that’s it. However, a lot of i3 WM users use dmenu as applications menu1 - Create a symbolic link to /usr/bindmenu just show executables that are on /usr/bin so what we need to do is create a symbolic link to our application to theresudo ln -s /your_app_path/executable /usr/bin/the_name_you_want_to_be_displayed_at_dmenu

title: How to manage bluetooth devices on i3 WM
snippet: DisclaimerWell, it actually isn’t related to i3 WM, i3 WM is just a window manager, it means it just adjust windows on your screen and that’s it. However, sometimes you want to connect some bluetooth devices on your PC and for that you certainly don’t want to go through a lot of commands on your shell, so just use blueman1 - Install bluemansudo dnf install blueman2 - Now you can manage your bluetooth devies :)

title: How to hide asterisks password in terminal Linux Mint
snippet: 1 - Go to sudoers.dcd /etc/sudoers.d2 - Rename 0pwfeedback to 0pwfeedback.disabledsudo mv 0pwfeedback 0pwfeedback.disabled3 - That’s done!

title: How to customize i3 WM font
snippet: 1 - First let’s make a backup of our original i3 WM configcp ~/.config/i3/config ~/.config/i3/config.ori2 - Edit i3 WM configI gonna use NVIM to edit the config, you can use whatever editor you wantnvim ~/.config/i3/config3 - Inside of config fileNow we’re gonna to change this linefont pango:monospace 8what I do is just copy and edit it for the font of my preference and comment the older line#font pango:monospace 8font pango:Hack Nerd Font:Regular 124 - Save the changes and restart i3 WMSuper + Shift + r

title: How to install fonts on linux
snippet: 1 - First download your fontFor this tutorial I’m gonna use Hack Nerd Font, you can get it here: Nerd Fonts download2 - Create .fonts directorymkdir ~/.fonts3 - Copy your fonts to .fonts directorycp ~/Downloads/Hack.zip ~/.fonts/4 - Unzip your fontsunzip ~/.fonts/Hack.zip -d ~/.fonts/5 - Delete unused filesrm -rf ~/.fonts/Hack.ziprm -rf ~/.fonts/*.mdrm -rf ~/Downloads/Hack.zip6 - Refresh fonts cachefc-cache -fv7 - Now you can set your font in whatever part of your system

title: Alacritty install and config guide
snippet: 1 - Install alacrittyI’m a fedora user, so I’m gonna use DNF but if you’re Ubuntu user try APT instead of DNF:sudo dnf install alacritty2 - Create config filenvim ~/.alacritty.toml3 - Inside of config file[shell]program = "/bin/zsh"[font]normal = { family = "Hack Nerd Font", style = "Regular" }size = 14[cursor]style = { shape = "Underline" }unfocused_hollow = false4 - Save it and open alacritty again

title: How to customize i3 status
snippet: 1 - First let’s make a backup of our original i3 status configcp /etc/i3status.conf ~/.config/i3/i3status.conf2 - Edit i3status.confI gonna use NVIM to edit the config, you can use whatever editor you wantsudo nvim /etc/i3status.conf3 - Inside of config fileWell now you do whatever you wanna do. What I like to do is to remove some info from i3status (I just comment it out)#order += "ipv6"#order += "wireless _first_"#order += "ethernet _first_"order += "battery all"#order += "disk /"#order += "load"order += "memory"order += "tztime local"4 - Save the changes and restart i3Super + Shift + r

title: Starting up with i3 WM shortcuts
snippet: These are some shortcuts I learned using i3 WM, I’ll update it as I learn Shortcut Action Super+return Opens terminal Super+d Open dmenu (a sort of app menu) Super+number Goes to virtual workspace with that number Super+Shift+e Exit i3 Super+Shift+number Move current focused app to virtual workspace with that number Super+Shift+q Kill current focused app Super+arrowkey Switch between focused app on screen Super+Shift+r Restart i3

title: How to setup FTP simple server on linux
snippet: Don’t use root user You can’t acess ftp if you only have root user, you gonna need to create another user1 - Install proftpd on linux serversudo apt install proftpd2 - Install FileZilla on client machineLinux:sudo apt install filezillaWindows:FileZilla linkInstallation: next, next, finish.3 - Open FileZillaFill out: Host: your server ip Username: your user (same of the linux login) Password: your password (same of the linux login) Port: 21Quickconnect, you’re in.

title: How to create windows 10 VM on Proxmox
snippet: 1 - Get windows 10 and Virtio-drivers ISO’sWindows 10Virtio drivers stable2 - Upload your ISO’s to proxmox server1 - First, click on local, go to ISO Images, after click on upload:2 - Now chose your ISO, and click on upload (WAIT FOR 100%):* You can change file name if you want to3 - Create VM1 - Now, let’s create the VM (virtual machine), First, click on Create VM (Up right):2 - Choose a name for your VM:3 - Choose your windows 10 ISO, and change Type to Microsoft Windows and version to 10/2016/2019, gonna be like this:4 - Check Qemu Agent box:5 - Change Bus/Device to SCSI, Cache to Write back, You can choose your Storage and Disk size (You can change disk size later):6 - Select how many cores and sockets you want (You can change it later):7 - Select how much memory you gonna give it (You can change it later):8 - Change model to VirtIO (paravirtualized) and disable firewall (You can change it later):9 - Now, check everything and after click on finish and wait for the VM be created:4 - Windows installation1 - First, we’re going to add our virtual drivers to installation, click on your VM, go to hardware section and click on Add, click on CD/DVD Drive:2 - Select your virtio drivers, change ID number to 1 and click on Add, probably is gonna be like this:3 - If everything’s correct, your hardware section has to be similar to this:4 - Go to Console section and click on Start Now:5 - Now, proceed with windows installation till you get to “Which type of installation do you want?”, Select Install windows (advanced):6 - As you can see, there’s no disk. So we have to load the drivers:7 - Browse:8 - Select the CD driver that we loaded in step 2:9 - Select vioscsi, amd64 and click ok:10 - Click next:11 - Now, as you can see, our disk is loaded (I added more 28GB):12 - Now do the same to NetKvm:13 - And the same to Balloon:14 - proceed with windows installation till get to desktop.5 - Desktop configuration1 - First, right click on windows logo and click on Device manager:2 - As you can see, we’ve to install some drivers, double left click on PCI Simple Communi…:3 - Click on Update Driver:4 - Select Browse my computer for driver software5 - Click on CD/DVD Drive with virtio drivers:6 - Click Next:7 - Click Install:8 - As you can see, everything is installed:9 - Open windows explorer, go to This PC, go to CD Drive with virtio drivers:10 - Open guest-agent:11 - Install qemu-ga-x86_64:12 - Now that everything’s installed, shutdown the machine, go to hardware section and remove Windows ISO and Virtio drivers:Documentation and UtilitiesProxmox offical documentationTutorial video

title: Oh-My-Zsh! Install and Config Guide
snippet: 1 - Install zsh and oh-my-zsh1 - First you’ve to install the shell zsh.I’m a fedora user, so I’m gonna use DNF but if you’re Ubuntu user try APT instead of DNF:sudo dnf install zsh2 - Install oh-my-zsh:sh -c "$(wget https://raw.github.com/ohmyzsh/ohmyzsh/master/tools/install.sh -O -)"3 - Set zsh as your default shell:chsh -s /usr/bin/zsh2 - Nerd Fonts (optional)Feel free to choose your nerd font: Nerd Fonts downloadI’m gonna use Hack Nerd Font.3 - PowerLevel10k (optional)PowerLevel10k is a theme to oh my zsh.1 - Download it:git clone --depth=1 https://github.com/romkatv/powerlevel10k.git ${ZSH_CUSTOM:-$HOME/.oh-my-zsh/custom}/themes/powerlevel10k2 - Set ZSH_THEME="powerlevel10k/powerlevel10k" in ~/.zshrc.ZSH_THEME="powerlevel10k/powerlevel10k"4 - zsh-syntax-highlighting (optional)zsh-syntax-highlighting is a syntax highlighter for shell commands.1 - Download it:git clone https://github.com/zsh-users/zsh-syntax-highlighting.git ${ZSH_CUSTOM:-~/.oh-my-zsh/custom}/plugins/zsh-syntax-highlighting2 - Set in your ~/.zshrc:plugins=( git zsh-syntax-highlighting)5 - zsh-autosuggestions (optional)zsh-autosuggestions is a autocomplete tool for your shell.1 - Download it:git clone https://github.com/zsh-users/zsh-autosuggestions ${ZSH_CUSTOM:-~/.oh-my-zsh/custom}/plugins/zsh-autosuggestions2 - Set in your ~/.zshrc:plugins=( git zsh-syntax-highlighting zsh-autosuggestions)Documentation and UtilitiesOh-My-Zsh offical documentationPowerLevel10k offical documentationzsh-syntax-highlighting offical documentationzsh-autosuggestions offical documentation

title: Markdown notebook
snippet: MarkdownMarkdown is a markup language similar to HTML but more simple. You can write everything in markdown. Especially documentation. My entire blog posts is written in markdown, every single documentation on github is written using markdown. What are you waiting to learn it? Here’s my notes of a course that I did to learn markdown.Titles# title 1## title 2### title 3#### title 4##### title 5###### title 6or # title 1 ### title 2 ##### title 3 ####### title 4 ######### title 5 ########### title 6 ######ortitle=====ortitle-----Paragraphtext text text__ &lt;- 2 spaces at end "break line"text text text &lt;- this, really break linetext text textExample with 2 spaces at end:Lorem Ipsum is simply dummy text of the printing and typesetting industry. Lorem Ipsum has been the industry’s standard dummy text ever since the 1500s, when an unknown printer took a galley of type and scrambled it to make a type specimen book. It has survived not only five centuries, but also the leap into electronic typesetting, remaining essentially unchanged.It was popularised in the 1960s with the release of Letraset sheets containing Lorem Ipsum passages, and more recently with desktop publishing software like Aldus PageMaker including versions of Lorem Ipsum.Highlights**bold** or __bold__*italic* or _italic_***bold italic*** or **_bold italic_** or __*bold italic*__~~scratched~~&gt; quoteHorizontal rule*** or * * * or ***...or --- or - - - or ---...or ___ or _ _ _ or ___...Unordered list* item 1* item 2* item 3or - item 1- item 2- item 3or + item 1+ item 2+ item 3or . item 1. item 2. item 3Ordered list1. 1. 1.2. or 1. result -&gt; 2. markdown follow the sequence of the first number 3. 1. 3.Link[text](link)[text](link "text if the user stop the mouse on the link")image![text](path)[![text](path)](link)Table|title|title||-----|-----||data |data |can be like this (but it's not recommended):|title|title||-|-||data|data|Alignment:left: |:-|right: |-:|center: |:-:|Example:table with data aligned on center:|title|title||:---:|:---:||data |data |Codecode in line `code` code block (can be a pair of 3 "~"):```languagecode``` Checkbox* [ ] item 1* [x] item 2 marked* [ ] item 3Emoji:smile:Documentation and UtilitiesMarkdown offical documentationMarkdown EmojisMarkdown web previewFree course on Udemy(in Portuguese)

title: Chirpy Survive Guide
snippet: DisclaimerThis post don’t replace the official documentation, It’s only a summary about what I think’s more important.Change avatar pictureCreate img/avatar inside assets folderPaste the picture that you want to be your avatar picture inside assets/img/avatar/Go to _config.yml line 86, fill it with the image path like i did:Change faviconCreate favicon inside assets/img folderGo to Real Favicon Generator, upload your image and config it, click on Generate your Favicons and HTML codeDownload the generated package, unzip and delete the following two from the extracted files: browserconfig.xml site.webmanifestAnd then copy the remaining image files to the directory assets/img/favicons/Run locallyFirst clone your repository:git clone reponame.github.ioFollow Jekyll documentation to install ruby and complementsGo to the project folder, open terminal inside it and do this command:bundleThe commands above is only for the first time you’re running the project locallyNow to run a local server:bundle exec jekyll sAfter a while, the local service will be published at http://127.0.0.1:4000.New post structureFolder: _postsFile name: YYYY-MM-DD-TITLE.mdHeader:---author: name: nametitle: titledate: YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS TTTTcategories: [cat1, cat2] # 1 or 2tags: [tag] # Always in lowercase---Tip: Brazillian TTTT is UTC-3.Tip2: Create posts inside assets/img folderOfficial documentationGetting StartedCustomize the FaviconWriting a New Post
